citation.article-title: Sulfitobacter pontiacus gen. nov., sp. nov. - a new heterotrophic bacterium from the Black Sea, specialized on sulfite oxidation.

p.s: Description of Sulfitobacter pontiacus gen. nov.
Sulfitobacter pontiacus (Sul.fi.to.bacter M.L. n. sulfitum, sulfite; M.L. masc. n. bacter, equivalent of Gr. neut. n. bacterion, a rod; M.L. masc. n. sulfitobacter, sulfite rod)
Gram-negative rod-shaped strictly aerobic heterotrophic eubacterium.
Depending on growth conditions, rods are either straight with sharpened ends or dumbbell-shaped with a tendency for polar growth, cell differentiation, and rosette formation.
Cells vary in size in a wide range of (0.45 - 1.3) x (2 - 5) μm.
Depending on growth conditions, cells may be motile by means of 1 - 5 subpolar flagella.
Growth in liquid medium is homogeneous.
On an acetate agar medium, colonies are colorless, flat, and translucent and have even margins, up to 5 mm in diameter.
Oxidase and catalase positive.
Does not grow chemolithoautotrophically on thiosulfate, sulfite, and H2 as electron donors.

Utilizes acetate, propionate, butyrate, pyruvate, lactate, gluconate, acids of the Krebs cycle (except citrate and cis-aconitate), glycerol, glutamate, proline, aspartate, asparagine, serine, α-alanine, ornithine, and arginine as the sole carbon and energy sources.
Poly-β-hydroxybutyrate is accumulated in cells grown on acetate.
Ammonium is used as the nitrogen source.
Growth in a mineral medium with acetate is stimulated by yeast extract and thiamine.
The respiratory chain includes cytochromes c551, b558, and cytochrome c oxidase of the aa3 type.
When growing organotrophically on acetate, the organism can oxidize thiosulfate, elemental sulfur, and sulfite to sulfate, the sulfite-oxidizing activity being higher by two orders of magnitude.
Grows in acetate-limited chemostat culture at extremely high sulfite concentrations.
Thiosulfate and sulfite stimulate acetate-dependent growth in a continuous culture.

Sulfite is oxidized by highly active inducible AMP-independent soluble sulfite oxidase that donates electrons from sulfite to the respiratory chain at the level of cytochrome c via soluble cytochrome c.
The G + C content of DNA is 62.1 ± 0.4 (Tm).
The member of α-3-subdivision of Proteobacteria.
Isolated from the water of H2S-O2 interface of the eastern part of the Black Sea.
Type species Sulfitobacter pontiacus.
